solution_line_template: First, we need to find the average number of apples per person. We start by adding the three totals together, getting {jim_apples}+{jane_apples}+{jerry_apples}=<<{jim_apples}+{jane_apples}+{jerry_apples}={total_apples}>>{total_apples} apples
To finish finding the average number, we perform {total_apples}/{number_of_people}= <<{total_apples}/{number_of_people}={average_apples}>>{average_apples} apples per person.

Since Jim has {jim_apples} apples, we divide the average of {average_apples} by Jim's total to find {average_apples}/{jim_apples}=<<{average_apples}/{jim_apples}={times_fit}>>{times_fit} times that Jim's amount can fit into the average.
